Triggering Event: In the hospital's quiet supply closet, he reaches for a box of gloves, his fingers brushing against a familiar pair left behind. Triggering Event: A grey drizzle taps against the window of his small apartment, echoing the dreary rhythm of his life. He sits alone at the kitchen table, a half-eaten sandwich untouched before him, as he stares at the empty chair across from him. A framed photograph catches his eye - a faded image of a smiling couple on their wedding day. His gaze lingers on her face, now blurred by time and tears. The silence is deafening, broken only by the distant hum of traffic outside. He feels the weight of years alone, each one a quiet echo of the life they'd planned together.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, it's so obvious that she left me for someone else. She must have found someone who loved her more than I ever could. They probably went on an amazing honeymoon, laughing and loving every moment together. It's just too much to bear.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

70-year-old scientist, John, sits at his cluttered desk, glasses perched on his nose, squinting at his laptop screen. His partner, Mary, enters the room, humming softly while putting away laundry. John sighs audibly as he realizes the Wi-Fi is down again, just when he needs it most for a critical data upload. He snaps, "Mary, could you please tell your nephew to stop streaming games on his phone? This is the third time this week!" Mary stops mid-hum and frowns, taken aback by John's abruptness.
Generated Assessment: John snapped, "You're either really lazy or a slacker! You can't even be bothered to charge your phone." Mary looked crestfallen, her eyes welling up with tears. She whispered, "Dad, I'm tired. The kids are being loud, and I have so much work. Just calm down." John huffed, "Fine, but you're choosing laziness over responsibility. Either you're a good parent or a slacker."

Triggering Event: An art gallery owner cancels her upcoming solo exhibition at the last minute, citing lack of interest from potential buyers. She had spent weeks preparing for it, and this was meant to be her first public showcase since losing her husband two years ago. The news arrives via an indifferent email while she's in her studio, paintbrush still in hand, surrounded by unfinished canvases that now feel like a waste of time.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, you know what? I'm glad the whole thing fell through. I mean, can't they see how much more important things are than some paintings? It doesn't even matter if they were good or bad; just look at all the money we could have wasted on advertising, printing catalogs, and traveling to promote them! Not to mention the stress I'd be under trying to sell those pieces. I've been so focused on getting everything perfect, but honestly, it wasn't worth it. My mind is already filled with a million other projects I need to work on, and now I'll just have to spend my precious time doing something else instead. Plus, I don't want to deal with people who don’t understand me or my art—those salespeople would probably just distract me from my real passions anyway. What really gets me is that no one cares about my work anymore. I guess it’s for the best; after all, my ex-husband always said I was too sensitive about my creations. He didn’t get why I put so much effort into them when there’s nothing out there that matters more than life itself. And let’s be honest, what does it even matter if anyone buys my paintings? They’re not going to change anything in this world. Just think about all the better things I could be doing right now—I could be working on my own project, or maybe even learning a new skill! Triggering Event: An empty seat at the dinner table, still set with his favorite dishes. The ticking clock echoing in the silent room. A forgotten letter from him tucked into a worn novel she's been trying to read for months.
Generated Assessment: She stared blankly at the half-eaten meal, her mind consumed by the thought that he might not be coming home tonight. What if I never see him again? What if he left me forever? What if this is just another cruel joke? Her thoughts were interrupted when she found the letter tucked between the pages of his favorite book. It was dated yesterday, but it looked like it had been there for weeks. She hesitated before opening it, fearing what she would find inside. As she read through the words, tears streamed down her face. He wasn't going anywhere; he loved her too much. But the pain lingered, and she couldn't shake off the feeling that everything was falling apart. She sat in silence, the ticking clock in the background making her anxious. What if time ran out completely? What if she lost him forever? What if she could never get back what was already gone?

Triggering Event: She stared at her laptop screen, fingers tapping impatiently as she waited for the code to compile. Five minutes ticked by, then ten. She let out a sigh of frustration, her third in the past hour. The once-silent apartment was filled with the hum of her computer and her own tense breathing. Another red error message popped up, mocking her. She slumped back in her chair, rubbing her temples. "Why won't you just work?" she muttered at the screen, feeling a familiar surge of frustration that had been her constant companion since the divorce.

Just look at all those other people who have finished their projects already. They must be geniuses compared to her. And what's worse is that she's wasting everyone's time with her incompetence. Why can't she just focus for once? I swear, every time she works, something goes wrong. First, she forgets to turn off the background noise, so we all have to deal with it again. Then, she tries to send files through email instead of using the cloud. We've lost count of how many times she's sent emails to herself because she forgot to CC someone. This isn't the first time; it's happened multiple times before, but now she thinks she's some kind of expert just because she fixed one issue. She doesn't listen to instructions, so she ends up messing everything up. When she does finally manage to finish something, it's always late, and there are usually mistakes. And don't even get me started on her excuses. "Oh, my dog ate my paper," or "My internet was down." How many times has she said that? You'd think she would have learned from previous mistakes, but nope, she

Triggering Event: He found her favorite dress, still hanging untouched in the closet. The emptiness of the house closed in as he held it to his face, inhaling the faded scent of her perfume.
Generated Assessment: He was devastated when she left him. I felt like I couldn't breathe. But then I realized that I didn't even know what made me feel this way. I thought about how much I loved her, but now I'm starting to question whether it was all just a lie. It feels so wrong to think that I could've done something to make her stay, but at the same time, I'm wondering if we were really meant to be together. I keep thinking back to our last conversation, trying to remember every word, every glance, every touch. It's like my mind is trying to fill in gaps where there are none. But then I saw her favorite dress, just sitting there in the closet. I don't know why, but holding it made me realize how empty everything feels now. The house used to be full of life, but it's just a hollow space with nothing but memories. I can almost smell the perfume she wore, but it doesn't give me comfort; it just makes me miss her more. I wish I had been strong enough to convince her to stay, but deep down, I know it wasn't true. I've always felt like I wasn't good enough for her, and maybe that’s what pushed her away. Now, I’m left here, feeling like I’ve lost myself too. I wonder if I’ll ever find someone else like her. Maybe I should try dating again, but the thought of moving on feels impossible. I just

Triggering Event: He noticed the canvas was slightly askew when he returned from his coffee break, and now he can't shake the feeling someone's been in his studio.
Generated Assessment: He just doesn’t trust anyone anymore. The whole office feels so suspicious; everyone’s always acting shady, and I can’t stand it. Even though there are plenty of honest people, they’re all tainted by the possibility that one might be involved. And don’t even get me started on how he’s always been distant lately. Now that I think about it, he’s been acting weird for months—every time I see him, he’s completely silent, never saying anything unless it’s about work. It’s as if he’s holding something back, but he won’t tell me what it is. What if he’s hiding something? What if he’s always doing this? I’m starting to feel like no one’s really who they say they are. Everyone has secrets, and I can’t put my finger on why, but it just feels wrong. Maybe he’s right to be cautious, but honestly, I’ve had enough of this stress. My anxiety is through the roof, and I just want things to go back to normal. But until then, I’ll keep watching him closely. I know he’s not telling me everything, but maybe he’s just being careful. Still, it’s hard to ignore those little signs—like how he kept looking at the canvas with an odd expression. What if he knows more than he’s letting on?

Triggering Event: A familiar face from her past, an old colleague, pushed past her in the crowded store aisle without acknowledging her greeting, murmuring instead about "the new girl" being more helpful.
Generated Assessment: Oh no! She's so rude again! I'm always treated this way when people don't know me well. It's never going to change, but it doesn't even matter anyway. People are always going to be selfish and inconsiderate towards me. I'm just so tired of feeling ignored and disrespected. The whole world is against me, and nothing ever changes. This will probably happen again tomorrow too.

Triggering Event: A parent approaches her after class, holding up a crumpled note from their child: "Mrs. T isn't teaching us anything new this year."
Generated Assessment: **Mrs. T's stupid lesson plan is about how we are going to have more homework than ever before. And if we don't get all our work done, Mrs. T will give us 2 points less per assignment, and we'll have to do 5 additional assignments. I'm telling you right now, she has no idea what she's doing. She doesn't care about our grades. We're just going to sit there for hours and watch her ramble on while we struggle to keep up with her outdated curriculum. If you think Mrs. T is smart, you must be out of your fucking mind.**
